title: SQL Maxis: Why We Ditched RabbitMQ and Replaced It with a Postgres Queue
dot: digraph{subgraph cluster_overall{label="Overall Change: RabbitMQ to Postgres Queue";"RabbitMQ"->"Postgres Queue";"RabbitMQ"[label="Initial choice, had issues"];"Postgres Queue"[label="New implementation, better reliability"];}subgraph cluster_rabbitmq_choice{label="Reasons for RabbitMQ";"Widely adopted"->"RabbitMQ";"Based on AMQP"->"RabbitMQ";"Mature & production - grade"->"RabbitMQ";"Easy to add to Helm chart"->"RabbitMQ";}subgraph cluster_rabbitmq_setup{label="RabbitMQ Setup";"RabbitMQ"->"One consumer per message";"RabbitMQ"->"Manual ACK messages";}subgraph cluster_rabbitmq_issues{label="RabbitMQ Issues";"RabbitMQ"->"Consumer reconnection issues";"RabbitMQ"->"Multi - threading bugs";"RabbitMQ"->"Job delays";"Job delays"->"Customer complaints";"Job delays"->"Root cause: Prefetching issue";}subgraph cluster_postgres_queue{label="Postgres Queue Features";"Postgres Queue"->"Backed by single table";"Postgres Queue"->"Publishers write, consumers read";"Postgres Queue"->"Maintain queue ordering";"Postgres Queue"->"Row - level locks";}subgraph cluster_postgres_queue_benefits{label="Postgres Queue Benefits";"Postgres Queue"->"Centralized application state";"Postgres Queue"->"Better understood by team";"Postgres Queue"->"Easier to tweak, monitor, debug";}}
